items.title: Obama’s Chance for a Fresh Start on a Climate-Smart Energy Quest
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: President Obama’s inaugural address stresses the need to press on energy frontiers and cut climate risks.

items.title: Energy Secretary Is Resigning After 4 Years Focused on Clean Technologies
items.author: By Matthew L. Wald
items.abstract: Energy Secretary Steven Chu, a winner of the Nobel Prize, will leave office soon, possibly by the end of this month.

items.title: That Tesla Data: What It Says and What It Doesn’t
items.author: By John M. Broder
items.abstract: About three hours into the trip, the reporter placed the first of about a dozen calls to Tesla personnel expressing concern about the car’s declining range.

items.title: Satellite Tracking of Middle East Aquifers Points to the End of ‘Data Denial’
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: Satellites offer a clear view of important shifts in Middle East water resources from a distance.

items.title: Controlling the ‘Smart Home’ With Tablets and Smartphones
items.author: By Nick Wingfield
items.abstract: Newer home automation technologies let mobile devices control functions like heating, lighting and home security.

items.title: Cyberwar: How Digital Threats Are Redefining National Security
items.author: By Tom Marshall
items.abstract: In this lesson, students learn about the scope of recent cyberattacks and what is being done to counter such threats. Then they consider the broader practical and ethical consequences of preparing for cyberwar.

items.title: Hoopla of TV, Wooing Ads to Digital Media
items.author: By Stuart Elliott and Tanzina Vega
items.abstract: Companies that produce digital content are putting on presentations this week in hopes of attracting advertising dollars from marketers and agencies.

items.title: New Climate Data Depict a City More at Risk
items.author: By Jenny Anderson
items.abstract: More than 800,000 New York City residents will live in flood zones by the 2050s, according to warnings issued by the Bloomberg administration, which hopes to encourage better preparation for climate change.
keywords: New York City Panel on Climate Change

items.title: James Martin, Technology Consultant and Oxford Benefactor, Dies at 79
items.author: By Bruce Weber
items.abstract: Mr. Martin was an influential figure in information technology who used his fortune to study the problems and opportunities confronting the 21st-century world.

items.title: Big Data Shrinks to Grow
items.author: By Quentin Hardy
items.abstract: It was a good year for Big Data — the term at least, and quite possibly the industry. But as masses of data and its subsequent analysis comes of age, many companies have found that they need to focus on a few specifics, rather than promise to change everything.

items.title: Far West Got Drier Last Year, Data Shows
items.author: By Henry Fountain
items.abstract: Although 2013 was a wetter than average year for the contiguous 48 states, scientists said, that statistic masked sharp regional differences.

items.title: Water-Cleaning Technology Could Help Farmers
items.author: By Todd Woody
items.abstract: A project developed by WaterFX, a start-up in drought-stricken California, exploits two things the Central Valley possesses in abundance — fallow land and sunshine — to cut desalinization costs.

items.title: Values and Data Meet at a Vatican Workshop on Sustaining Humanity on a Flourishing Planet
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: The Vatican hosts a meeting considering the mix of science, technology and values-laden choices that will determine the quality of life — human and otherwise — on Earth in coming decades.

items.title: Smarter Electricity in New York
items.author: By The Editorial Board
items.abstract: The state proposal to decentralize the system to smaller stations that use solar or wind power could lead a national revolution.

items.title: Marc Andreessen on the Future of Silicon Valley(s), and the Next Big Technology
items.author: By Nick Bilton
items.abstract: The noted investor and entrepreneur discusses the valley’s investment climate, his faith in virtual reality and digital currency — and his long tweets.

items.title: Year-End Roundup, 2013-14 | Math, Science, Health and Technology
items.author: By Shannon Doyne
items.abstract: All the Science, Math, Health and Technology lessons we published this year — with links back to our 2010, 2011, 2012 and 2013 collections.

items.title: Technology as a Path to Product Transparency
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: A look at online portals that can offer consumers a view of the labor and environmental conditions behind the products on store shelves.

items.title: The World According to Maxwell Smart, Part 1
items.author: By Thomas L. Friedman
items.abstract: “Get Smart” was ahead of its time. The world today is cleaving into “Control” and “Kaos.”
keywords: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

items.title: Hiring Data Isn’t Strong Enough to Lift Democrats’ Hopes for November
items.author: By Jackie Calmes
items.abstract: The tepid growth in August will probably not change voters’ gloom about the economy much, which voters usually hold the president’s party responsible.

items.title: In Forecasting Health Costs, Let Technology Be Your Guide
items.author: By Austin Frakt
items.abstract: The ability to sustain lower growth in costs will depend in large part on how investments in health care technology are encouraged.
keywords: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

items.title: Digital Tools for Discovery: 10 New Ways to Search and Explore The New York Times
items.author: By Michael Gonchar and Katherine Schulten
items.abstract: Practical tips and tools to help students and teachers find wonderful things in The New York Times.

items.title: Year-End Roundup, 2014-15 | Math, Science, Health and Technology
items.author: By The Learning Network
items.abstract: A collection of all the science, math, health and technology lesson ideas that appeared on The Learning Network in the 2014-15 school year.

items.title: HP to Power Texas Data Centers With Wind Energy
items.author: By Diane Cardwell
items.abstract: A combination of falling prices and greater pressure for companies to show action to fight climate change has led corporations to buy renewable energy.

items.title: Awash in Data, Thirsting for Truth
items.author: By Margaret Sullivan
items.abstract: Shoe-leather reporting and data journalism don’t have to be at odds in the search for truth.

items.title: Digital Ads Sell Candidates and Causes, in 15-Second Bursts
items.author: By Ashley Parker
items.abstract: Campaigns have turned to short, attention-grabbing digital ads for mobile devices that are sharper and more creative in presenting a political message.

items.title: Museum Specimens Find New Life Online
items.author: By Erik Olsen
items.abstract: Scientific organizations around the world are turning to digital technology to reveal collections that have long been hidden.

items.title: Yuck to Wow: Explaining Science and Technology in Museums
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: “The Secret World Inside You” at the American Museum of Natural History and “Silicon City: Computer History Made in New York” at the New-York Historical Society tackle abstract concepts.

items.title: A Digital Team Is Helping Obama Find His Voice Online
items.author: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis
items.abstract: About 20 aides are dedicated to building a social media presence in the president’s own voice to help develop a more personal rapport on multiple platforms.

items.title: 1953 | Immersive Technology Debuts, in the Movie Ads
items.author: By David W. Dunlap
items.abstract: Three-dimensional viewing experiences are nothing new for Times readers, who first noticed objects popping off the page over 60 years ago.

items.title: Internet Yields Uneven Dividends and May Widen Inequality, Report Says
items.author: By Somini Sengupta
items.abstract: The vast changes wrought by technology have not expanded economic opportunities or improved access to basic public services in ways that many had expected.
keywords: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

items.title: As Economy Slows, Experts Call on China to Drop Growth Target
items.author: By Edward Wong
items.abstract: A growing number of analysts say China’s practice of setting an annual target for growth actually hurts the economy and encourages officials to falsify data.

items.title: S.E.C. Orders Exxon Mobil Shareholder Vote on Climate Data
items.author: By Liam Stack
items.abstract: A resolution, if approved, would force the energy giant to outline for investors how its profitability may be affected by climate change.

items.title: China’s Carbon Emissions May Have Peaked, but It’s Hazy
items.author: By Edward Wong
items.abstract: There could be important consequences if such emissions are falling more than a decade earlier than expected, but finding the answer is difficult.

items.title: Earth to Audience: How Andrew Revkin’s Blog Built a Digital Conversation About Climate Change
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: Dot Earth invites readers around the world to advise, comment, post videos and even argue — to a point.

items.title: Technology Transforms How Insurers Calculate Risk
items.author: By Quentin Hardy
items.abstract: New methods of collecting and evaluating information allow insurers to determine more precise premiums based on each customer’s particular risk.

items.title: Exxon Mobil Backs FuelCell Effort to Advance Carbon Capture Technology
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: The energy giant is investing in FuelCell Energy’s technology for carbon capture and sequestration, a potential way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

items.title: A Computer Security Start-Up Turns the Tables on Hackers
items.author: By Nicole Perlroth
items.abstract: Area 1 Security heads off cyberattacks by tapping into servers known to be compromised by hackers, and monitoring the attackers’ activities.

items.title: Finance Is the Master Technology — and It’s Funded the World
items.author: By Felix Martin
items.abstract: An economist argues that civilization’s rise hangs on the power of finance.
keywords: Money Changes Everything: How Finance Made Civilization Possible (Book)

items.title: Can Carbon Capture Technology Prosper Under Trump?
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: Progress has come in fits and starts, but supporters believe a new plant in Texas may provide a clear economic argument for fighting global warming.

items.title: Falcons, Drones, Data: A Winery Battles Climate Change
items.author: By David Gelles
items.abstract: Jackson Family Wines is among California winemakers employing both high-tech and old-school techniques to adapt to hotter, drier conditions.

items.title: Smart Approaches, Not Strong-Arm Tactics, to Jobs
items.author: By Thomas L. Friedman
items.abstract: Democrats need to take the long view.

items.title: China’s Intelligent Weaponry Gets Smarter
items.author: By John Markoff and Matthew Rosenberg
items.abstract: The United States no longer has a strategic monopoly on a technology that is widely seen as the key factor in the next generation of warfare.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: No Data Manipulation in 2015 Climate Study, Researchers Say
items.author: By Henry Fountain
items.abstract: A British tabloid said American government scientists overstated global temperatures to influence climate talks. Other scientists say that did not happen.
keywords: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

items.title: Trump Leaves Science Jobs Vacant, Troubling Critics
items.author: By Cecilia Kang and Michael D. Shear
items.abstract: Scores of scientists and technology experts have left the White House, and conservatives — and the president — have questioned whether they need to be replaced.

items.title: To Curb Global Warming, Science Fiction May Become Fact
items.author: By Eduardo Porter
items.abstract: Geoengineering, providing methods to offset climate change by applying scientific fixes rather than changing old habits, may have found its moment.
keywords: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

items.title: Scientists Fear Climate Data Gap as Trump Aims at Satellites
items.author: By Henry Fountain
items.abstract: Even if Congress votes to keep NASA environmental missions, the nation’s climate monitoring faces challenges, researchers say.

items.title: A Monday Holiday Around the World, and May Hiring Data Is Due
items.author: By The New York Times
items.abstract: Many financial markets will close for national holidays. As for jobs, Wall Street analysts expect that 176,000 people joined the work force.

items.title: Trump, Prioritizing Economy Over Climate, Cites Disputed Premises
items.author: By Mark Landler, Brad Plumer and Linda Qiu
items.abstract: The president’s withdrawal from the Paris accord seemed more about his belief in the potential to save jobs and ease economic burdens than any disbelief in climate science.

items.title: At Pruitt’s E.P.A.: No Studies, No Data, No Rules
items.author: By The Editorial Board
items.abstract: The president sticks his head in the sand as his administration’s hostility toward science continues.

items.title: Facebook Fallout Deals Blow to Mercers’ Political Clout
items.author: By Nicholas Confessore and David Gelles
items.abstract: Rebekah and Robert Mercer, the conservative donors behind Cambridge Analytica, are trying to limit damage to their nascent empire and deflect scrutiny from their business endeavors.

items.title: The Frugal Five
items.abstract: The five writers who have contributed to the Frugal Traveler column over the last 25 years share stories, travel philosophies and plenty of tips.

items.title: Latest Sign of China’s Slowdown: A Technology Cash Crunch
items.author: By Li Yuan
items.abstract: Long awash in money, the country’s start-up scene has seen an unprecedented downturn. That could be a bad sign for the rest of the Chinese economy.

items.title: Too Many Politicians Misuse and Abuse Crime Data
items.author: By David Eads
items.abstract: When sloppily cherry-picking isolated numbers, they disrespect our intelligence and our democracy.

items.title: Are Museums Still Important in the Digital Age?
items.author: By Michael Gonchar
items.abstract: Do museums still matter? Are they worth actually stepping inside to see collections firsthand? And are they worth protecting for the future?

items.title: North Carolina, Warned of Rising Seas, Chose to Favor Development
items.author: By John Schwartz and Richard Fausset
items.abstract: The legislature passed a law in 2012 to ignore evidence of sharp long-term rises in sea level, so the state’s fragile coastline would go on booming.

items.title: Is Technology Harming Teenagers?
items.abstract: Readers critique a psychiatrist’s essay debunking claims that technology is causing an epidemic of anxiety.

items.title: The Sun Sets. The Wind Dies. But Energy Data Is Relentless.
items.author: By Ivan Penn
items.abstract: Alternative power sources have upended the electric grid. Ivan Penn, who covers the beat, discusses the changes and how he keeps track of them.

items.title: For BP’s Chief, Technology and the Environment Matter Most
items.author: By Stanley Reed
items.abstract: Nearly a decade after the oil rig disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, Bob Dudley talks about his firm’s focus on the future.

items.title: Here’s How the Shutdown Is Delaying Climate Data and Undercutting Scientists
items.author: By Kendra Pierre-Louis
items.abstract: A key global temperature report isn’t coming out this week because of missing data, and some long-term research projects are at risk.

items.title: Digital Media: What Went Wrong
items.author: By Edmund Lee
items.abstract: For years, BuzzFeed seemed to be leading the journalism industry toward a brave new future. Now that it has stumbled, the way ahead looks more old-school than ever.

items.title: The Week in Tech: Our Future Robots Will Need Super-Smart Safety Checks
items.author: By Jamie Condliffe
items.abstract: Software looks to be at the heart of the recent Ethiopian Airlines crash. Safety approval of such systems will only get harder as technology advances.
keywords: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

items.title: Democrats Seek Young Voters, and the Memes That Move Them
items.author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
items.abstract: Democratic 2020 hopefuls have taken note of the potential power of millennial and Generation Z voters. But effectively reaching them is the hard part.

items.title: DealBook Briefing: What a Digital Iron Curtain Could Mean for Tech
items.abstract: A grace period in corporate America’s freeze-out of Huawei might not help the tech company very much.

items.title: One Thing You Can Do: Drive Smarter
items.author: By Lisa Friedman and Eduardo Garcia
items.abstract: Also this week, climate report cards for Democratic candidates.

items.title: How 5 Data Dynamos Do Their Jobs
items.author: By Lindsey Rogers Cook
items.abstract: Reporters from across the newsroom describe the many ways in which they increasingly rely on datasets and spreadsheets to create groundbreaking work.

items.title: Can ‘Big Data’ Help Fight Big Fires? Firefighters Are Betting on It
items.author: By Jose A. Del Real
items.abstract: As wildfires grow more intense, fire chiefs in Southern California are looking to big data and machine learning for help in managing fast-moving blazes.

items.title: Moody’s Buys Climate Data Firm, Signaling New Scrutiny of Climate Risks
items.author: By Christopher Flavelle
items.abstract: The bond-rating agency's purchase of Four Twenty Seven suggests that governments and companies that ignore climate threats could be penalized.
keywords: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies

items.title: Biden Is Smart to Talk About a Republican V.P.
items.author: By David Leonhardt
items.abstract: Don’t believe the hype.

items.title: 2019 Was a Record Year for Ocean Temperatures, Data Show
items.author: By Kendra Pierre-Louis
items.abstract: A new analysis found 2019 was the hottest for the world’s oceans. The five hottest years have also been in the past five years.

items.title: One Thing You Can Do: Make Smart Donations
items.author: By Susan Shain, Shola Lawal and Brad Plumer
items.abstract: Also this week, African climate activists and a popular Berkeley class

items.title: Dangerous Numbers? Teaching About Data and Statistics Using the Coronavirus Outbreak
items.author: By Patrick Honner
items.abstract: In this guest lesson, the math teacher Patrick Honner helps students practice looking critically at data in the news.

items.title: In Negotiations, Givers Are Smarter Than Takers
items.author: By Adam Grant
items.abstract: Generosity is a sign of intelligence, and givers are the rising tide that lifts all boats.
keywords: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

items.title: Trump Won the Internet. Democrats Are Scrambling to Take It Back.
items.author: By Jim Rutenberg and Matthew Rosenberg
items.abstract: In the era of big data, memes and disinformation, the Democrats are trying to regain their digital edge as the president and his loyalists dictate the terms of debate.

items.title: A.I. Is Helping Scientists Understand an Ocean’s Worth of Data
items.author: By Tatiana Schlossberg
items.abstract: Machine-learning applications are proving to be especially useful to the scientific community studying the planet’s largest bodies of water.

items.title: Earth Day’s Gone Digital. Here’s Where to Find It.
items.author: By Laurel Graeber
items.abstract: New York offers many ways to celebrate online. You can hike, play environmental games, conduct experiments, meet scientists and blast into space — all without leaving home.
keywords: Museum of the City of New York

items.title: The Smart Way to Grow Roses
items.author: By Margaret Roach
items.abstract: It’s the season for ordering roses. Here’s how to choose the right ones — and how to grow them sustainably once you’ve got them.

items.title: Can Data Make Life Better? And Other Letters to the Editor
items.abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.

items.title: As Locusts Swarmed East Africa, This Tech Helped Squash Them
items.author: By Rachel Nuwer
items.abstract: A hastily formed crowdsourcing operation to contain the insects in Kenya, Ethiopia and Somalia could help manage climate-related disasters everywhere.
keywords: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

items.title: In Coinbase’s Rise, a Reminder: Cryptocurrencies Use Lots of Energy
items.author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
items.abstract: The company’s stock market arrival establishes Bitcoin and other digital currencies in the traditional financial landscape. It also elevates a technology with astonishing environmental costs.

items.title: The White House warns that the U.S. lags behind China on developing clean technologies.
items.author: By Katie Rogers
items.abstract: A new report warns that, without a significant investment in research and development, America could become dependent on its competitors.

items.title: A Million Years of Data Confirms: Monsoons Are Likely to Get Worse
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: The annual summer monsoon in South Asia begins this month. A new study points to more destructive storms.

items.title: Born on the Left, Data for Progress Comes of Age in Biden’s Washington
items.author: By Lisa Lerer
items.abstract: A liberal think tank has grown comfortable with mainstream influence. Other activists say that being “normie” means it’s selling out.

items.title: Biden raised issues of human rights and digital disruption.
items.author: By Michael D. Shear
items.abstract: The American leader aimed to look strong on security while also not making too many waves.

items.title: What Technology Could Reduce Heat Deaths? Trees.
items.author: By Catrin Einhorn
items.abstract: At a time when climate change is making heat waves more frequent and more severe, trees are stationary superheroes: They can lower urban temperatures 10 lifesaving degrees, scientists say.

items.title: The C.D.C.’s New Challenge? Grappling With Imperfect Science
items.author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
items.abstract: The Omicron coronavirus variant is moving much faster than researchers can, worsening a longstanding problem: The agency must make tough decisions with scant data.
keywords: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

items.title: Lisa Goddard, 55, Dies; Brought Climate Data to Those Who Needed It
items.author: By Clay Risen
items.abstract: She helped show government agencies around the world how to predict upcoming droughts, flooding and other extreme weather events.
keywords: International Research Institute for Climate and Society (Columbia University)

items.title: Can We Get Smarter About Disinformation?
items.author: By Jay Caspian Kang
items.abstract: It’s on us to become more discerning.

items.title: Carmakers Race to Control Next-Generation Battery Technology
items.author: By Jack Ewing and Eric Lipton
items.abstract: The prize: batteries that would be cheaper, faster to charge and less vulnerable to raw material shortages. Whoever gets there first will have a major advantage.

items.title: What the Silicon Valley Prophet Sees on the Horizon
items.author: By John Markoff
items.abstract: Stewart Brand coined the term “personal computer” and was one of the first to envision what digital technology would become. He knows it got messy. He thinks tech can clean itself up.

items.title: Forecasters Face Loss of Data as Weather Balloon Flights Are Cut
items.author: By Henry Fountain
items.abstract: Disruptions to supplies of hydrogen and helium have led the National Weather Service to cancel routine launches at some sites.

items.title: We Have the Technology to Stop Superspreading Without Masks
items.author: By Donald K. Milton, Edward A. Nardell and David Michaels
items.abstract: Buildings need to disinfect the air.

items.title: Buffalo Shooting Highlights Rise of Hate Crimes Against Black Americans
items.author: By Audra D. S. Burch and Luke Vander Ploeg
items.abstract: The federal data shows a recent spike in assaults, threats and incidents of bias.

items.title: White House Aims to Reflect the Environment in Economic Data
items.author: By Lydia DePillis
items.abstract: The Biden administration has set out to measure the economic value of ecosystems, offering new statistics to weigh in policy decisions.

items.title: Why Are You Seeing So Many Bad Digital Ads Now?
items.author: By Tiffany Hsu
items.abstract: Scrolling past ads has rarely been enjoyable. But in recent months, people say the experience seems so much worse.

items.title: Unwanted Connection: Who Has Control of Your Smart Home?
items.author: By Anna Kodé
items.abstract: The proliferation of devices creates more opportunities for people to lose access or power over aspects of the home.

items.title: The Real-World Costs of the Digital Race for Bitcoin
items.author: By Gabriel J.X. Dance, Tim Wallace and Zach Levitt
items.abstract: Bitcoin mines cash in on electricity — by devouring it, selling it, even turning it off — and they cause immense pollution. In many cases, the public pays a price.

items.title: BuzzFeed News, Which Dragged Media Into the Digital Age, Shuts Down
items.author: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
items.abstract: A quirky upstart that became a Pulitzer Prize-winning operation fell prey to the punishing economics of digital publishing.

items.title: New Rules for Power Plants Could Give Carbon Capture a Boost. Here’s How.
items.author: By Brad Plumer
items.abstract: The technology has struggled to gain traction, but strict new emissions limits for gas and coal stations could encourage broader adoption.

items.title: A Once-Promising Green Energy Technology Hits a Roadblock
items.author: By Ian Austen
items.abstract: Tidal power turbines operating on the Bay of Fundy in Nova Scotia were suspended after the company running them was unable to get a permit to continue testing.
